body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
I appreciate you guys so much.

I got into an argument with a family member once because he swore up and down hate speech wasn't protected speech. I definitely don't personally agree with ideals behind hate speech because I try to live by if you're not hurting anyone then do what the fuck you want.  That doesn't mean I don't think it shouldn't be protected.

The issue with banning hate speech is the interpretation of what hate speech encompasses.  It just leads to bad things. I mean look at all the gun laws and regulations we have now. That all started in the 60s trying to prohibit blacks from carrying.  

An attack on one constitutional right, is an attack on all constitutional rights. The Supreme Court rules on something called precedence.  Basically is like this ruling was specifically for this, which can be applied to this situation.  This doesn't, or almost never, blurs into another constitutional right, but it makes it easier to them to ignore it.  

Ben Franklin once said, "Those who would give up essential Liberty, to purchase a little temporary Safety, deserve neither Liberty nor Safety."  Bans at a corporate level aren't legally binding outside their platform or property, but it changes the Hive Mind.  Imagine having to get a license to say fuck.  Why we I need a license to carry a gun?

body:
Excellent, I'm glad to hear that you guys are taking a detailed and principled stance on this. 

On the topic though, +loli was banned because "Reason: Sexualizing minors is not allowed." However, [US law on this issue is not clear and generally state dependent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_status_of_drawn_pornography_depicting_minors#United_States), and "Sexualizing minors is not allowed" could mean anything from [disallowing 90% of anime](https://imgur.com/xt40y9z) to [letting anything go so long as the depicted character is >= 18](https://pics.me.me/im-twenty-l-anime-irl-12830737.png). 

It might be a big ask, but can you guys ~~explicitly spell out~~ provide clarification for your policy on loli and put it in the ToS? I run multiple anime/hentai guilds and need clear guidelines on what is and is not acceptable. Ideally, I'd also like to see some reference to relevant US or state law, similar to what you guys did here.

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

  1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
  2. A specific place or time, and
  3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

Excellent, I'm glad to hear that you guys are taking a detailed and principled stance on this. 

On the topic though, +loli was banned because "Reason: Sexualizing minors is not allowed." However, [US law on this issue is not clear and generally state dependent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_status_of_drawn_pornography_depicting_minors#United_States), and "Sexualizing minors is not allowed" could mean anything from [disallowing 90% of anime](https://imgur.com/xt40y9z) to [letting anything go so long as the depicted character is >= 18](https://pics.me.me/im-twenty-l-anime-irl-12830737.png). 

It might be a big ask, but can you guys ~~explicitly spell out~~ provide clarification for your policy on loli and put it in the ToS? I run multiple anime/hentai guilds and need clear guidelines on what is and is not acceptable. Ideally, I'd also like to see some reference to relevant US or state law, similar to what you guys did here.

body:
So part where you say that you may take 'appropriate action' where something is a 'credible threat' seems like a copout to me. The specific reason for the imminent lawless danger standard (which you probably came across in your research) is to remove that kind of interpretability from the governments powers. I think the same thing should apply to ruquus. There should be explicit and clear rules so much so that no person adjuticating speech has to rely on feelings of intent or credibility to make a decision. This is intended to remove personal bias from decisionmaking. 
A good rule of thumb when deciding on rules like this is to think "how could the worst person I could think of abuse this". Again I'll say, appropriate action and credible threat (to whom?) are left undefined in a way that allows for too much leeyway. 
That being said, I'm happy you guys obviously care about free speech on ruqqus and are doing your research.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

Read and understood. But I wonder: Does it include politicians?
Totally apart from the fact that they are barely human, no politician should ever be trusted unless he lives in constant fear that he will have to account to his citizens for his actions.
Besides. They all have security details. Anyone smart enough to plan an effective act of violence against a politician isn't likely to post his intent on a public site. And it's easy enough to email a screenshot to the appropriate office, whether it be police, sheriff, or FBI.
We could argue that the whole "boogaloo" thing is an incitement to political violence, and is just waiting for a trigger or "GO" command. Such a thing was actually *desired* by the people who founded the US. They wanted us to be able to drag politicians out of office when they get uppity.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
You did right. Sometimes you have to act on discretion when faced with a situation and only then review your decisions (or the rules) if needed. Rules are not perfect, cannot cover all situations and should never be an impediment for you to protect the site when a situation is developing. I’ve been trying to explain this for days now, but people can be very obtuse *if they choose to*.

My only objection was the apparent lack of communication with us the users. Posts like this nullify any criticism. Thanks for this, @captainmeta4, @kek and all the staff.

P.S.: any ETA for an official admin stance on the usage of alts (or bots) to game the platform with kick evasion, vote manipulation, spam etc.?

About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
*Waah, you're censoring us! This is new Reddit!!!* /s

Jokes apart props for dealing with this issue, it's important to draw the line - it ensures Ruqqus' continued existance and trueness to the original goal. I also like you're publicly telling us about something you're reverting; I don't know if the bans were a mistake but mistakes are bound to happen, so the ability to humbly recognize and fix them is precious.

With this in mind, [I think the troll here has a point](https://ruqqus.com/post/1bin/free-speech-and-calls-to-violence/44rz): it's easy to circumvent the guidelines by not specifying place or time. Since I've been discussing free speech in Ruqqus quite a bit, do you mind some input?

We can split what's said into three parts: 

* description - a statement about something/one; e.g. "dragons exist!", "the Sun is hot", or "Jews did 9/11"\*.
* opinion - a subjective judgment about something; e.g. "well done steak is abominable!", "I like winter", or "Jews are bad".
* performance - something you do with language; e.g. a boss saying "you're fired!", someone telling you "pass the salt, please", or a Neonazi saying "we should kill the Jews!".

The rules should never prohibit descriptions (even if wrong) or opinions (even if morally wrong). They should only focus on performance because, even if it's something we do with language, it's more akin to behaviour than to speech proper.

Calls to violence are *always* performance. It's always someone telling someone else what to do. Ditto for threats, it's always someone trying to provoke a reaction in someone else (fear of consequences). 

With that in mind, I think better guidelines for call to violence would be: **"a call to violence is a statement inciting, requesting, or encouraging people to do something harmful against a certain target"**. This is surprisingly objective (it doesn't deal with intentions, but the discourse being shown) and damn hard to cheese out.

[inb4 sorry Jewish folks for using you guys as example.]

By the way. Adam, kek, ark... thank you three for this platform. Seriously - you guys are awesome.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

parent.body:
So part where you say that you may take 'appropriate action' where something is a 'credible threat' seems like a copout to me. The specific reason for the imminent lawless danger standard (which you probably came across in your research) is to remove that kind of interpretability from the governments powers. I think the same thing should apply to ruquus. There should be explicit and clear rules so much so that no person adjuticating speech has to rely on feelings of intent or credibility to make a decision. This is intended to remove personal bias from decisionmaking. 
A good rule of thumb when deciding on rules like this is to think "how could the worst person I could think of abuse this". Again I'll say, appropriate action and credible threat (to whom?) are left undefined in a way that allows for too much leeyway. 
That being said, I'm happy you guys obviously care about free speech on ruqqus and are doing your research.

body: No middle ground is possible on this subject. Either “taxation without consent is robbery,” or it is not. If it is not, then any number of men, who choose, may at any time associate; call themselves a government; assume absolute authority over all weaker than themselves; plunder them at will; and kill them if they resist. If, on the other hand, taxation without consent is robbery, it necessarily follows that every man who has not consented to be taxed, has the same natural right to defend his property against a taxgatherer, that he has to defend it against a highwayman.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

I appreciate you guys so much.

I got into an argument with a family member once because he swore up and down hate speech wasn't protected speech. I definitely don't personally agree with ideals behind hate speech because I try to live by if you're not hurting anyone then do what the fuck you want.  That doesn't mean I don't think it shouldn't be protected.

The issue with banning hate speech is the interpretation of what hate speech encompasses.  It just leads to bad things. I mean look at all the gun laws and regulations we have now. That all started in the 60s trying to prohibit blacks from carrying.  

An attack on one constitutional right, is an attack on all constitutional rights. The Supreme Court rules on something called precedence.  Basically is like this ruling was specifically for this, which can be applied to this situation.  This doesn't, or almost never, blurs into another constitutional right, but it makes it easier to them to ignore it.  

Ben Franklin once said, "Those who would give up essential Liberty, to purchase a little temporary Safety, deserve neither Liberty nor Safety."  Bans at a corporate level aren't legally binding outside their platform or property, but it changes the Hive Mind.  Imagine having to get a license to say fuck.  Why we I need a license to carry a gun?

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

You claim to understand the supreme court interpretation of the 1st amendment, and clearly have no clue what the supreme court via Brandenburg v. Ohio establishes. Unless "imminent" lawless action is likely to occur as a direct consequence of the statement, the violent statement is absolutely legal. 

Someone jokingly threatening to slap you with a pickle, without knowing your name and address and no intention of performing the action is protected free speech. 

If you do claim it is a genuine violent threat please explain why you aren't reporting the person to the police. You are clearly not in fear of the action's imminent occurrence. Your feelings are hurt, nothing more.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
I went here getting ready to write some scathing anti-censorship stuff, but this is a thoughtful post and I don't see anything wrong with these criteria.

Could you imagine if Ruqqus ignored a post which contained all of the above and something actually happened? The site would be absolutely done.

My only concern is what latitude you're going to take when you determine you have 'good reason', and if it will be applied fairly to all groups. Right now you look like you're going in the right direction there, and hopefully this won't get corrupted in future.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

  3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
Yeah, this is historically the hard part when dealing with “free speech refugees.”  Voat started out OK, but too many of the influx were literal racists, and they completely dominated the site and scared off all the moderates.

If you allow free speech, there’s always going to be the kind of scum that use triple parentheses around Jewish names, etc., you just have to hope that they stay below some critical percentage of the population to avoid a snowball effect.

Reddit’s latest purge does seem to have pushed more moderate voices out than any previous purge, so hopefully we’ve got a high enough percentage of the population here that will shout down the mouth-breathing hate freaks while still allowing freedom of debate.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
The owners of Ruqqus won't be culpable for anything other than ignoring a legal, signed, and specific warrant from a police officer with jurisdiction. 

There's two ways to go with this.  Common carrier status where the people carrying the box are not liable for what assholes shit into the box. Fedex isn't responsible for terrorists shipping Anthrax. Or curated, edited, publications that are liable for the content they produce.    The NY Times can't publish mob hit orders and claim they have no control. Of course, Fedex also can't ban shipping Trump hats while the NY Times can choose to ignore people who want them to publish their stories.

Control and liability, or hands-off and no culpability. There's no two ways about it, and we should absolutely disallow corporations trying to have all the control and none of the responsibility.

Or curated, edited, publications that are liable for the content they produce. The NY Times can't publish mob hit orders and claim they have no control. Of course, Fedex also can't ban shipping Trump hats while the NY Times can choose to ignore people who want them to publish their stories.

Control and liability, or hands-off and no culpability. There's no two ways about it, and we should absolutely disallow corporations trying to have all the control and none of the responsibility.

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. 1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
Constitutionally protected free speech as per the 1st Amendment applies only to Congress.  "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances."

Ruqqus is not Congress, ergo, Ruqqus can ban whatever they damn well please.

I therefore posit that anyone who would cite the 1st Amendment as a basis for a claim should READ it, first.

"I *want* to go on a sniping spree and pop me 100 zipperheads at the mall." is protected speech.

"I'm going to the mall with my Dragunov to explode the melons of a hundred honkies." is not.

Exhibit A denotes a desire to do something, Exhibit B denotes intent.

"Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances."

Ruqqus is not Congress, ergo, Ruqqus can ban whatever they damn well please.

I therefore posit that anyone who would cite the 1st Amendment as a basis for a claim should READ it, first.

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

"I'm going to the mall with my Dragunov to explode the melons of a hundred honkies." is not.

Exhibit A denotes a desire to do something, Exhibit B denotes intent.

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we decided to crack down on hate speech developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

  1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
  2. A specific place or time, and
  3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
It's interesting that you're going so hard against a book, one that you brought up in the first place haha. American Masons these days can get their 32nd in in like 2 years, my Masonic system doesn't use numbered degrees past the 3rd, there's that. 

You're absolutely right in that I know nothing, compared to the knowledge in the world, mundane and supernatural, my knowledge is like .000000000000000001% of 0.000000000001% of being close to anything nearing what can be considered knowledge, so the best I can do is patiently drink in what's in my cup and apply it where I can.

Also I just told you I could never be a '33' because I can't even be perfected (which is fine by me, there are some really cool, less travelled paths that could benefit from younger members for ritual and stuff) because I'm not a Trinitarian Christian. 

But I think your interest can be steered in a healthy way - if you're not too old, if you calm down a bit in your angry passion, you could join a lodge and work your way up to 32nd, then work on yourself and the community to get bestowed the honour of the 33rd, and see what's it all about! You can still join if you're older, but I find it takes at least 20 years of work to be granted the 33rd, so don't come in expecting it one time.

Also, as a bonus - Gaelic‽ You didn't really think the Rosslyn schism has an impact on Antient Freemasonry, do you? That's an addition by some Hermetically bent druids, I think you could dig deeper than that, you seem to be interested in some hidden history.

Remember the biggest way to impact the world, is to start with yourself :)

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

>I think that's probably why the Brandenburg test doesn't make any rules specific to the semantics of the language used. It only cares if the speech is likely to produce imminent lawlessness.

Most likely - it's treating it as an act, not as a discourse: you did something that caused a lawless action, so that thing is wrong.

Maybe the test could be outright used by the devs "as is"?

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
I want a society based on voluntary interaction, mutual consent and free association. 

I also want roads and defense and would gladly pay for those things voluntarily. My problem is part deontological - initiation of force is wrong; and part consequential - allowing people to forcibly take from others to fund things completely removes market forces from a giant sector of the economy and leads to the situations we have today where probably 95% of most people's tax dollars are going to things they do not support (endless war, mass incarceration, gross human rights violations, police brutality... and on and on. )

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

parent.body:
It's interesting that you're going so hard against a book, one that you brought up in the first place haha. American Masons these days can get their 32nd in in like 2 years, my Masonic system doesn't use numbered degrees past the 3rd, there's that. 

You're absolutely right in that I know nothing, compared to the knowledge in the world, mundane and supernatural, my knowledge is like .000000000000000001% of 0.000000000001% of being close to anything nearing what can be considered knowledge, so the best I can do is patiently drink in what's in my cup and apply it where I can.

Also I just told you I could never be a '33' because I can't even be perfected (which is fine by me, there are some really cool, less travelled paths that could benefit from younger members for ritual and stuff) because I'm not a Trinitarian Christian. 

But I think your interest can be steered in a healthy way - if you're not too old, if you calm down a bit in your angry passion, you could join a lodge and work your way up to 32nd, then work on yourself and the community to get bestowed the honour of the 33rd, and see what's it all about! You can still join if you're older, but I find it takes at least 20 years of work to be granted the 33rd, so don't come in expecting it one time.

Also, as a bonus - Gaelic‽ You didn't really think the Rosslyn schism has an impact on Antient Freemasonry, do you? That's an addition by some Hermetically bent druids, I think you could dig deeper than that, you seem to be interested in some hidden history.

Remember the biggest way to impact the world, is to start with yourself :)

No, my system doesn't use a numerical order (like cardinal or ordinal) we have a different route, it's like branching paths - you have to be invited in, can skip some, some are optional - that type of thing. Some say it goes "beyond" the Scottish Rite, to me they're all lateral. Think of it as 3rd degree being grade 12, and the other degrees (except a few, but we're not going into that because, well I have to keep some administrative secrets) as extra curriculars.

If you know, you know - simple as :). The same way I don't tell my wife's friends about my wife's secrets, I'm not going to just say the secrets of the Craft. It's not out of fear for my life (which you would know, I wouldn't have a fear of death), but just honor and the ability to keep a secret.
