About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
If a Ruqqus user was a government representative, they would not be allowed to censor responses as their private account now represents the government in an official capacity. (1st and 14th amendment case, Knight First Amendment Institute for Columbia University v. Trump)

In a private (non-government) use case, the "legality" resides inside the terms of service. The first amendment still allows for "editorial discretion" of the hosting company in it's vague/subjective capacity.

The Constitution and Bill of Rights limit government action, not individual action. (Nyabwa v. Facebook)

Couple good references below if you're interested in free speech and the internet:

https://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/social-clashes-digital-free-speech

 “Regulating Online Content Moderation”

"Extremist Speech, Compelled Conformity, and Censorship Creep”

“The New Governors: The People, Rules, and Processes Governing Online Speech.”

"Hate: Why We Should Resist It with Free Speech, Not Censorship"

body:
I'm fairly neutral on whether or not it should be allowed on Ruqqus. As I understand it, it is in fact a bit of a grey area in US law(see the wiki article I linked), so I don't blame the admins for implementing the rule. (That being said, I personally believe that theres nothing wrong with loli since they're just drawings and no real children are involved.)

The real issue is that as a GM I need clear guidelines on what is and is not acceptable. As written, the ToS bans 90% of anime, (characters are often sexualized, and frequently <18) while letting through egregious shit because "she's canonically 500 years old". I'm almost certain this is not the intent of the admins so some clarification is necessary. 

For now, I'm just going with "if it looks like loli I'll get rid of it" since I think that's the spirit of the ToS, and I won't change that policy unless I get further guidance from the admins. 

@kek, @captainmeta4

It is not because men have made laws, that personality, liberty, and property exist. On the contrary, it is because personality, liberty, and property exist beforehand, that men make laws. What, then, is law? As I have said elsewhere, it is the collective organization of the individual right to lawful defense.

body: The meaning of this is simply We, the people of the United States, acting freely and voluntarily as individuals, consent and agree that we will cooperate with each other in sustaining such a government as is provided for in this Constitution. The necessity for the consent of “the people” is implied in this declaration. The whole authority of the Constitution rests upon it. If they did not consent, it was of no validity. Of course it had no validity, except as between those who actually consented. No one’s consent could be presumed against him, without his actual consent being given, any more than in the case of any other contract to pay money, or render service. And to make it binding upon any one, his signature, or other positive evidence of consent, was as necessary as in the case of any other-contract. If the instrument meant to say that any of “the people of the United States” would be bound by it, who did not consent, it was a usurpation and a lie. The most that can be inferred from the form, “We, the people,” is, that the instrument offered membership to all “the people of the United States;” leaving it for them to accept or refuse it, at their pleasure.

body: The fact is that the government, like a highwayman, says to a man: “Your money, or your life.” And many, if not most, taxes are paid under the compulsion of that threat. The government does not, indeed, waylay a man in a lonely place, spring upon him from the roadside, and, holding a pistol to his head, proceed to rifle his pockets. But the robbery is none the less a robbery on that account; and it is far more dastardly and shameful. The highwayman takes solely upon himself the responsibility, danger, and crime of his own act. He does not pretend that he has any rightful claim to your money, or that he intends to use it for your own benefit. He does not pretend to be anything but a robber. He has not acquired impudence enough to profess to be merely a “protector,” and that he takes men’s money against their will, merely to enable him to “protect” those infatuated travellers, who feel perfectly able to protect themselves, or do not appreciate his peculiar system of protection. He is too sensible a man to make such professions as these. Furthermore, having taken your money, he leaves you, as you wish him to do. He does not persist in following you on the road, against your will; assuming to be your rightful “sovereign,” on account of the “protection” he affords you. He does not keep “protecting” you, by commanding you to bow down and serve him; by requiring you to do this, and forbidding you to do that; by robbing you of more money as often as he finds it for his interest or pleasure to do so; and by branding you as a rebel, a traitor, and an enemy to your country, and shooting you down without mercy, if you dispute his authority, or resist his demands. He is too much of a gentleman to be guilty of such impostures, and insults, and villainies as these. In short, he does not, in addition to robbing you, attempt to make you either his dupe or his slave.

parent.body: The meaning of this is simply We, the people of the United States, acting freely and voluntarily as individuals, consent and agree that we will cooperate with each other in sustaining such a government as is provided for in this Constitution. The necessity for the consent of “the people” is implied in this declaration. The whole authority of the Constitution rests upon it. If they did not consent, it was of no validity. Of course it had no validity, except as between those who actually consented. No one’s consent could be presumed against him, without his actual consent being given, any more than in the case of any other contract to pay money, or render service. And to make it binding upon any one, his signature, or other positive evidence of consent, was as necessary as in the case of any other-contract. If the instrument meant to say that any of “the people of the United States” would be bound by it, who did not consent, it was a usurpation and a lie. The most that can be inferred from the form, “We, the people,” is, that the instrument offered membership to all “the people of the United States;” leaving it for them to accept or refuse it, at their pleasure.

body:
I disagree. Citizens can't avoid the public square, but you can definitely avoid sites like this one. In fact, it's quite hard to find sites like ruqqus. I would also say that most people wouldn't know what Reddit was if you asked them. I think Reddit counts as a truck stop bathroom wall on steroids, like most websites that aren't the major social media platforms.

Reddit used to be a cool site for focused communities - the old sidebar still suggests that you create a sub for your home town or favourite sports team - but Reddit has evolved beyond that into a proper commercial enterprise now and is trying to make the jump from 'bathroom wall on steroids' to a respectable media website. That requires a shift back towards the old, distributive, broadcast TV model, because babies can't chew steak.

body:
In my opinion, the best medium term strategy would be to revoke legal protections for platforms while allowing promoting a free platform as a valid defense, while also immediately revoking all subsidies to platforms (ideally all tech companies). 

I don't think treating platforms as public goods will do any good in the long run because it will just make it harder to run decentralized internet services. And a more decentralized internet is absolutely essential. The more centralized the internet becomes, the fewer points of failure there are for Internet freedom to be lost.

That being said, I consider myself more pragmatic on this issue and am willing to consider any straightforward policy that won't harm decentralization

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
I think we are agreeing, mostly, and I was just less concise in my comment. 

Yes, they can have terms of service, which are not strictly simply abiding by the law, and still be considered neutral platforms and not publishers. 

And neutral platforms are not required to act as government entities. This is exactly true. 

But there are responsibilities which come from being a publisher, which entails more than simply deciding ToS (which really are supposed to be applied equally on what is defined as a neutral platform). 

So, for instance, on Parler, they do not allow porn. Period, end of story, no matter what kind. 

But when platforms get into allowing some to say a thing and others get banned for the same thing, they have become the same kind of gatekeeper as publishers- which are not neutral, nor government agencies - which come with legal responsibilities as to the content on their site. 

So, I think I was skewing the discussion a little (realized this as I was typing), because in regards to the free speech portion, you’re spot on... they are allowed to have Terms of Service and still be neutral platforms. 

I think I was discussing more when they go out of bounds of section 230 and plunge into being publishers, denying that they are, and still being seen as not editing and approving or disapproving speech. 

I will definitely read the article. Thank you! :)

If a Ruqqus user was a government representative, they would not be allowed to censor responses as their private account now represents the government in an official capacity. (1st and 14th amendment case, Knight First Amendment Institute for Columbia University v. Trump)

In a private (non-government) use case, the "legality" resides inside the terms of service. The first amendment still allows for "editorial discretion" of the hosting company in it's vague/subjective capacity.

The Constitution and Bill of Rights limit government action, not individual action. (Nyabwa v. Facebook)

Couple good references below if you're interested in free speech and the internet:

https://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/social-clashes-digital-free-speech

 “Regulating Online Content Moderation”

"Extremist Speech, Compelled Conformity, and Censorship Creep”

“The New Governors: The People, Rules, and Processes Governing Online Speech.”

"Hate: Why We Should Resist It with Free Speech, Not Censorship"

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

I'm fairly neutral on whether or not it should be allowed on Ruqqus. As I understand it, it is in fact a bit of a grey area in US law(see the wiki article I linked), so I don't blame the admins for implementing the rule. (That being said, I personally believe that theres nothing wrong with loli since they're just drawings and no real children are involved.)

The real issue is that as a GM I need clear guidelines on what is and is not acceptable. As written, the ToS bans 90% of anime, (characters are often sexualized, and frequently <18) while letting through egregious shit because "she's canonically 500 years old". I'm almost certain this is not the intent of the admins so some clarification is necessary. 

For now, I'm just going with "if it looks like loli I'll get rid of it" since I think that's the spirit of the ToS, and I won't change that policy unless I get further guidance from the admins. 

@kek, @captainmeta4

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

parent.body: The fact is that the government, like a highwayman, says to a man: “Your money, or your life.” And many, if not most, taxes are paid under the compulsion of that threat. The government does not, indeed, waylay a man in a lonely place, spring upon him from the roadside, and, holding a pistol to his head, proceed to rifle his pockets. But the robbery is none the less a robbery on that account; and it is far more dastardly and shameful. The highwayman takes solely upon himself the responsibility, danger, and crime of his own act. He does not pretend that he has any rightful claim to your money, or that he intends to use it for your own benefit. He does not pretend to be anything but a robber. He has not acquired impudence enough to profess to be merely a “protector,” and that he takes men’s money against their will, merely to enable him to “protect” those infatuated travellers, who feel perfectly able to protect themselves, or do not appreciate his peculiar system of protection. He is too sensible a man to make such professions as these. Furthermore, having taken your money, he leaves you, as you wish him to do. He does not persist in following you on the road, against your will; assuming to be your rightful “sovereign,” on account of the “protection” he affords you. He does not keep “protecting” you, by commanding you to bow down and serve him; by requiring you to do this, and forbidding you to do that; by robbing you of more money as often as he finds it for his interest or pleasure to do so; and by branding you as a rebel, a traitor, and an enemy to your country, and shooting you down without mercy, if you dispute his authority, or resist his demands. He is too much of a gentleman to be guilty of such impostures, and insults, and villainies as these. In short, he does not, in addition to robbing you, attempt to make you either his dupe or his slave.

But the robbery is none the less a robbery on that account; and it is far more dastardly and shameful. The highwayman takes solely upon himself the responsibility, danger, and crime of his own act. He does not pretend that he has any rightful claim to your money, or that he intends to use it for your own benefit. He does not pretend to be anything but a robber. He has not acquired impudence enough to profess to be merely a “protector,” and that he takes men’s money against their will, merely to enable him to “protect” those infatuated travellers, who feel perfectly able to protect themselves, or do not appreciate his peculiar system of protection. He is too sensible a man to make such professions as these. Furthermore, having taken your money, he leaves you, as you wish him to do. He does not persist in following you on the road, against your will; assuming to be your rightful “sovereign,” on account of the “protection” he affords you. He does not keep “protecting” you, by commanding you to bow down and serve him; by requiring you to do this, and forbidding you to do that; by robbing you of more money as often as he finds it for his interest or pleasure to do so; and by branding you as a rebel, a traitor, and an enemy to your country, and shooting you down without mercy, if you dispute his authority, or resist his demands. He is too much of a gentleman to be guilty of such impostures, and insults, and villainies as these. In short, he does not, in addition to robbing you, attempt to make you either his dupe or his slave.

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

body:
https://ruqqus.com/help/faq

What about hate speech?

Hate speech is protected by the First Amendment. You may find it obnoxious and vile, but someone somewhere probably finds something about you obnoxious too. Rest assured that your controversial views will not result in a ban from Ruqqus.

Other social media platforms have clearly demonstrated a dangerous and slippery slope from banning "hate speech", to banning speech that is merely distasteful, to banning content based on the political preferences of the platform's leadership. Ruqqus refuses to go down that path.

From a practical standpoint, we believe hateful users are best dealt with by allowing them to air their rage in an environment where they can be exposed to corrective information, rather than forced to fester in secret.

About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam

It's not even up to Ruqqus.  Hosting content that SCOTUS has previously deemed unprotected exposes Ruqqus to legal action.  Calls to violence are not protected speech, as decided by SCOTUS.  "Incitement" is a crime.

https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/373
